        if (count %2 != p_array[i]) {

Wait, but __builtin_popcount is a GCC extension. If we need to use standard C, we can write a function to count the bits.

Alternatively, implement a bit count function.

Implementing bit count:

int count_bits(int x) {

    int count =0;

    while (x) {

        count += x &1;

        x >>=1;

    }

    return count;

}

Thus, replace __builtin_popcount with count_bits.

Now, putting all together.

Now, the code structure:

#include <stdio.h>

#include <stdlib.h>

#include <string.h>

#define MAX_LINE 1000

int main() {

    int n, m;

    if (scanf("%d %d", &n, &m) != 2) {

        return 1;

    }

    // Read m lines for li.

    // Each line's elements after first are stored in li[i].

    // Need to read each line's elements after first.

    // Allocate arrays for li and lengths.

    int **li = malloc(m * sizeof(int*));

    int *lengths = malloc(m * sizeof(int));

    for (int i=0; i<m; i++) {

        char line[MAX_LINE];

        fgets(line, MAX_LINE, stdin);

        // Parse the line into integers, skipping first.

        int count =0;

        int *temp = malloc(100 * sizeof(int)); // arbitrary initial size, but may need to realloc.

        char *token = strtok(line, " ");

        // Skip first token.

        token = strtok(NULL, " ");

        while (token != NULL) {

            temp[count++] = atoi(token);

            token = strtok(NULL, " ");

        }

        // Allocate the actual size.

        li[i] = malloc(count * sizeof(int));

        memcpy(li[i], temp, count * sizeof(int));

        lengths[i] = count;

        free(temp);

    }

    // Read p array.

    char p_line[MAX_LINE];

    fgets(p_line, MAX_LINE, stdin);

    int *p_array = malloc(m * sizeof(int));

    int p_count =0;

    char *token = strtok(p_line, " ");

    while (token != NULL && p_count < m) {

        p_array[p_count++] = atoi(token);

        token = strtok(NULL, " ");

    }

    if (p_count != m) {

        // error, but assume input is correct.

    }

    // Now, collect all elements in li into present array.

    int present[n+1]; // 1-based.

    memset(present, 0, (n+1)*sizeof(int));

    for (int i=0; i<m; i++) {

        int *u = li[i];

        int len = lengths[i];

        for (int j=0; j < len; j++) {

            int x = u[j];

            if (x >=1 && x <=n) {

                present[x] =1;

            }

        }

    }

    // Compute q_size and elements array.

    int q_size =0;

    for (int x=1; x<=n; x++) {

        if (present[x]) q_size++;

    }

    int *elements = malloc(q_size * sizeof(int));

    int idx=0;

    for (int x=1; x<=n; x++) {

        if (present[x]) {

            elements[idx++] =x;

        }

    }

    // Create pos_of_element array.

    int pos_of_element[n+1]; // initialized to -1?

    memset(pos_of_element, -1, (n+1)*sizeof(int));

    for (int i=0; i<q_size; i++) {

        int x = elements[i];

        pos_of_element[x] =i;

    }

    // Precompute mask_u for each u in li.

    int *mask_u = malloc(m * sizeof(int));

    for (int i=0; i<m; i++) {

        int *u = li[i];

        int len = lengths[i];

        int mask =0;

        for (int j=0; j < len; j++) {

            int x = u[j];

            int pos = pos_of_element[x];

            if (pos != -1) {

                mask |= (1 << pos);

            }

        }

        mask_u[i] = mask;

    }

    // Compute v_size.

    int v_size = n - q_size;

    int multiplier = 1 << v_size;

    // Iterate all subsets.

    int ans1 =0;

    for (int subset_mask=0; subset_mask < (1 << q_size); subset_mask++) {

        bool valid = true;

        for (int i=0; i<m; i++) {

            int current_mask = mask_u[i];

            int common = subset_mask & current_mask;

            int count =0;

            while (common) {

                count += common &1;

                common >>=1;

            }

            if (count %2 != p_array[i]) {

                valid = false;

                break;

            }

        }

        if (valid) {

            ans1 += multiplier;

        }

    }

    // Now compute ans2 using the third program's logic.

    int N = ans1;

    int ans2 =0;

    for (int i=1; i<=N; i++) {

        int q = N /i;

        ans2 += i * q * (q +1) /2;

    }

    printf("%d\n", ans2);

    // Free all allocated memory.

    for (int i=0; i<m; i++) {

        free(li[i]);

    }

    free(li);

    free(lengths);

    free(p_array);

    free(elements);

    free(mask_u);

    return 0;

}

Wait, but in the code above, the count_bits function is implemented inline with a loop. I replaced __builtin_popcount with a loop counting the bits.

Testing this code for possible edge cases.

Edge case 1: when q is empty (v_size =n). Then multiplier is 1<<n. But if n is large, this could overflow. But the problem may assume that the first program's ans is manageable.

Another edge case: when m=0? But according to the first program's code, m is read as an integer, so perhaps m can be zero, but then the code may have issues. But the problem's input may ensure m is at least 1.

Another possible issue: when the elements in the lists are outside 1..n. But according to the problem's first program, v is 1..n minus q, so elements outside 1..n are not part of q. Thus, in the code, when collecting present[x], we check if x is between 1 and n. So elements outside are ignored.

Thus, the code should handle that.
